intro: Sinapis polymorpha, commonly known as wild mustard, is an annual flowering plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other economically important crops like cabbage and broccoli. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with hairy stems and alternate leaves that are lance-shaped and have a slightly serrated edge. Its small, yellow flowers are arranged in racemes and bloom from late spring to early summer. The plant produces small, round pods that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind and can germinate in a variety of soil types.
